column3: 1)	" Mr. Kraft
column4: I believe that the American people
column5: in the next four years under a Ford administration
column6: will be called upon to make those necessary sacrifices to preserve the peace which we have. Which means
column7: of course
column8: that uh - we will have to maintain an adequate military capability - which means
column9: of course
column10: that we will have to add a uh - I think uh - a few billion dollars to our defense appropriations to make certain that we have adequate uh -strategic forces - adequate conventional forces. I think the American people will be called upon to uh - uh - be in the forefront in giving leadership to the solution of those problems that must be solved in the Middle East
column11: in southern Africa
column12: and any problems that might arise in the Pacific. The American people will be called upon to tighten their belts a bit in meeting some of the problems that we face domestically. I don't think that uh - America can go on a big spending spree with a whole lot of new programs uh - that would add significantly to the federal budget. I believe that the American people
column13: if given the leadership that I would expect to give
column14: would be willing to give this thrust to preserve the peace and the necessary restraint at home to hold the lid on spending so that we could
column15: I think
column16: have a long overdue and totally justified tax decrease for the middle-income people. And then
column17: with the economy that would be generated from a restraint on spending
column18: and a tax uh reduction primarily for the middle-income people
column19: then I think the American people would be willing to make those sacrifices for peace and prosperity in the next uh - four years.

column1: Surely
column3: overlapping. Doesn't your policy really imply that we're going to have a fairly high rate of unemployment over a fairly long time
column4: that growth is gonna be fairly slow
column5: and that we're not gonna be able to do much - very much in the next four or five years to meet the basic agenda of our national needs in the cities
column6: in health
column7: uh in transit and a whole lot of things like that.

column1: Not at all. overlapping
No
column3: we're spending very significant amounts of money now
column4: some $200 billion a year
column5: almost 50 percent of our total federal expenditure uh - by the federal government at the present time for human needs. Now we will probably need to increase that to same extent. But we don't have to have - growth in spending that will blow the lid off and add to the problems of inflation. I believe we can meet the problems within the cities of this country and still uh - give a tax reduction. I proposed
column6: as you know
column7: a reduction to increase the personal exemption from seven hundred and fifty to a thousand dollars. With the fiscal program that I have
column8: and if you look at the projections
column9: it shows that we will reduce unemployment
column10: that we will continue to win the battle against inflation
column11: and at the same time give the kind of quality of life that I believe is possible in America. Uh - a job
column12: a home for all those that'll work and save for it
column13: uh - safety in the streets
column14: uh - health that is a - health care that is affordable. These things can be done if we have the right vision and the right restraint and the right leadership.

column1: Well I might say first of all that I think in case of the Carter administration the sacrifices would be much less. Mr. Ford's own uh - environmental agency has projected a 10 percent unemployment rate by 1978 if he's uh - president. The American people are ready to make sacrifices if they are part of the process. If they know that they will be helping to make decisions and won't be excluded from being an involved party to the national purpose. The major effort we must put forward is to put our people back to work. And I think that this uh - is one example where uh - a lot of people have selfish
column2: grasping ideas now. I remember 1973 in the depth of the uh - energy crisis when President Nixon called on the American people to make a sacrifice
column3: to cut down on the waste of uh - gasoline
column4: to cut down on the uh - speed of automobiles. It was a - a tremendous surge of patriotism
column5: that ""I want to make a sacrifice for my country."" I think we uh - could call together
column6: with strong leadership in the White House
column7: business
column8: industry and labor
column9: and say let's have voluntary price restraints. Let's lay down some guidelines so we don't have continuing inflation. We can also have a- an end to the extremes. We now have one extreme for instance
column10: of some welfare recipients
column11: who by taking advantage of the welfare laws
column12: the housing laws
column13: the uh - Medicaid uh - laws
column14: and the uh - food stamp laws
column15: make over $10 thousand a year and uh - they don't have to pay any taxes on it. At the other extreme
column16: uh - just 1 percent of the richest people in our country derive 25 percent of all the tax benefits. So both those extremes grasp for advantage and the person who has to pay that expense is the middle-income family who's still working for a living and they have to pay for the rich who have privilege
column17: and for the poor who are not working. But I think uh - uh - a balanced approach
column18: with everybody being part of it and a striving for unselfishness
column19: could help as it did in 1973 to let people sacrifice for their own country. I know I'm ready for it. I think the American people are too.

column3: 10)	" I would not work hard to support any of those. Uh - we've always had
column4: I think
column5: a lot of constitutional amendments proposed
column6: but the passage of them has been uh - fairly slow
column7: and uh - few and far between. In the two-hundred-year history there's been a very uh - cautious approach to this. We - quite often we have a transient problem. I - I'm strongly against a- abortion. I think abortion's wrong. I don't think the government oughta do anything to encourage abortion. But I don't favor a constitutional amendment on the subject. But short of the constitutional amendment
column8: and within the confines of the Supreme Court rulings
column9: I'll do everything I can to minimize the need for abortions with better sex education
column10: family planning
column11: with better adoptive procedures. I personally don't believe that the federal government oughta finance abortions
column12: but I - I draw the line and don't support a constitutional amendment. However
column13: I honor the right of people who seek the constitutional amendments on school busing
column14: on uh - prayer in the schools and an abortion. But among those you named
column15: I won't actively work for the passage of any of them.

column1: support the uh - Republican uh - platform
column2: which calls for the constitutional amendment that would uh - outlaw abortions. I favor the particular constitutional amendment that would turn over to the states the uh - individual right to the voters in those states uh - the chance to make a decision by public referendum. Uh I call that the people amendment. I think if you really believe that the people of a state ought to make a decision on a matter of this kind that uh - we ought to have a federal constitutional amendment that would permit each one of the fifty states to make the choice. Uh - I think this is a responsible and a proper way to proceed. Uhh - I believe also that uh - there is some merit to a - an amendment that uh - uh - Senator Everett Dirksen uh - proposed very frequently
column3: an amendment that would uh - change the court decision as far as voluntary prayer in public schools. Uh - it seems to me that there should have - be an opportunity
column4: uh - as long as it's voluntary
column5: as long as there is no uh - compulsion whatsoever
column6: that uh - an individual ought to have that right. So in those two cases I think uh - such uh - a constitutional amendment would be proper
column7: and I really don't think in either case they're trivial matters. I think they're matters of very deep conviction
column8: as far as many
column9: many people in this country believe. And therefore
column10: they shouldn't be treated lightly. But they're matters that are ah - important. And in those two cases
column11: I would favor them.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 13)	" Well
column4: Mr. Kraft
column5: uh - I violently disagree with your assessment. And I don't think the record justifies the conclusion that you come to. Uh - let me uh - talk about uh - the economic announcements that were made just this past week. Yes
column6: it was announced that the uh - GNP real growth in the third quarter was at 4 percent. But do you realize that over the last ten years that's a higher figure than the average growth during that ten-year period? Now it's lower than the nine-point-point-two percent growth in the first quarter
column7: and it's lower than the uh 5 percent growth in the second quarter. But every economist - liberal
column8: conservative that I'm familiar with - recognizes that in the fourth quarter of this year and in the fifth quar- uh - the first quarter of next year that we'll have an increase in real GNP. But now let's talk about the pluses that came out this week. We had an 18 percent increase in housing starts. We had a substantial increase in new permits for housing. As a matter of fact
column9: based on the announcement this week
column10: there will be at an annual rate of a million
column11: eight hundred and some thousand new houses built
column12: which is a tremendous increase over last year and a substantial increase over the earlier part of this year. Now in addition
column13: we had a very - some very good news in the reduction in the rate of inflation. And inflation hits everybody: those who are working and those who are on welfare. The rate of inflation
column14: as announced just the other day
column15: is under 5 percent; and the uh - 4.4 percent that was indicated at the time of the 4 percent GNP was less than the 5.4 percent. It means that the American buyer is getting a better bargain today because inflation is less.

column1: With all due respect to President Ford
column2: I think he ought to be ashamed of mentioning that statement
column3: because we have the highest unemployment rate now than we had at any time between the Great Depression caused by Herbert Hoover and the time President Ford took office. We've got seven and a half million people out of jobs. Since he's been in office
column4: two and a half million more American people have lost their jobs. In the last four months alone
column5: five hundred thousand Americans have gone on the unemployment roll. In the last month
column6: we've had a net loss of one hundred and sixty-three thousand jobs. Anybody who says that the inflation rate is in good shape now ought to talk to the housewives. One of the overwhelming results that I've seen in the polls is that people feel that you can't plan anymore. There's no way to make a prediction that my family might be able to own a home or to put my kid through college. Savings accounts are losing money instead of gaining money. Inflation is robbing us. Under the present administration - Nixon's and Ford's - we've had three times the inflation rate that we experienced under President Johnson and President Kennedy. The economic growth is less than half today what it was at the beginning of this year. And housing starts - he compares the housing starts with last year. I don't blame him
column7: because in 1975 we had fewer housing starts in this country
column8: fewer homes built
column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column9: than any year since 1940. That's thirty-five years. And we've got a 35 percent unemployment rate in many areas of this country among construction workers. And Mr. Ford hasn't done anything about it. And I think this shows a callous indifference to the families that have suffered so much. He has vetoed bills passed by Congress within the congressional budget guidelines job opportunities for two million Americans. We'll never have a balanced budget
column10: we'll never meet the needs of our people
column11: we'll never control the inflationary spiral
column12: as long as we have seven and a half or eight million people out of work
column13: who are looking for jobs. And we've probably got two and a half more million people who are not looking for jobs any more
column14: because they've given up hope. That is a very serious indictment of this administration. It's probably the worst one of all.

column3: 14)	" Well
column4: that's not exactly an accurate description of what happened. When I was that far ahead
column5: it was immediately following the Democratic Convention
column6: and before the Republican Convention. At that time
column7: uh - 25 or 30 percent of the Reagan supporters said that they would not support President Ford. But as occurred at the end of the con- Democratic Convention
column8: the Republican Party unified itself. And I think immediately following the Republican Convention
column9: there was about a ten-point spread. I believe that to be accurate
column10: I had 49 percent; President Ford
column11: 39 percent. Uh - the polls uh - are good indications of fluctuations
column12: but they vary widely one from another. And the only poll I've ever followed is the one that uh - you know
column13: is taken on election day. I was in uh - thirty primaries in the spring
column14: and uh - at first it was obvious that I didn't have any standing in the poll. As a matter of fact
column15: I think when Gallup ran their first poll in December of 1975 they didn't put my name on the list. They had thirty-five people on the list. My name wasn't even there. And at the beginning of the year I had about 2 percent. So the polls to me are interesting
column16: but they don't determine
column17: you know
column18: my hopes or - or my despair. I campaign among people. I've never depended on powerful political figures to put me in office. I have a direct relationship with hundreds of people around - hundreds of thousands around the country who actively campaign for me. In Georgia alone
column19: for instance
column20: I got 84 percent of the vote
column21: and I think there were fourteen people uh - in addition to myself on the ballot
column22: and Governor Wallace had been very strong in Georgia. That's an overwhelming support from my own people who know me best. And today
column23: we have about five hundred Georgians at their own expense - just working people who believe in me - spread around the country uh - involved in the political campaign. So
column24: the polls are interesting
column25: but uh - I don't know how to explain the fluctuation. I think a lot of it uh - depends on current events - uh - sometimes foreign affairs
column26: sometimes domestic affairs. But I think our hold uh - of support among those who uh - are crucial to the election has been fairly steady. And my success in the primary season was
column27: I think
column29: from someone who's from outside Washington
column30: who - who never has been a part of the Washington establishment. And I think that we'll have good results uh - on November the second for myself and I hope for the country.

column1: I think uh - the uh - increase and the uh - prospects as far as I'm concerned and the I - less favorable prospects for Governor Carter
column2: reflect that Governor Carter uh - is inconsistent in many of the positions that he takes. He tends to distort on a number of occasions. Uh - just a moment ago
column3: for example
column4: uh - he uh - was indicating that uh - uh - in the 1950s
column5: for example
column6: uh - unemployment was very low. He fails to point out that uh - in the 1950s we were engaged in the war in Vietnam. We - I mean in Korea - we had uh - three million five hundred thousand young men uh - in the Army
column7: Navy
column8: Air Force and Marines. That's not the way to end unemployment or to reduce unemployment. At the present time we're at peace. We have reduced the number of people in the Army
column9: Navy
column10: Air Force and Marines from three million
column11: one hundred - three million
column12: five hundred thousand to two mil- lion one hundred thousand. We are not at war. We have reduced the military manpower by a million four hundred thousand. If we had that many more people in the Army
column13: the Navy
column14: the Air Force
column15: and Marines
column16: our unemployment figure would be considerably less. But this administration doesn't believe the way to reduce unemployment is to go to war
column17: or to increase the number of people in the military. So you cannot compare unemployment
column19: uh - with the present time with the 1950s
column20: because the then administration had people in the military - they were at war
column21: they were fighting overseas
column22: and this administration has reduced the size of the military by a million four hundred thousand. They're in the civilian labor market and they're not fighting anywhere around the world today.

column3: 14)	" Well
column4: that's not exactly an accurate description of what happened. When I was that far ahead
column5: it was immediately following the Democratic Convention
column6: and before the Republican Convention. At that time
column7: uh - 25 or 30 percent of the Reagan supporters said that they would not support President Ford. But as occurred at the end of the con- Democratic Convention
column8: the Republican Party unified itself. And I think immediately following the Republican Convention
column9: there was about a ten-point spread. I believe that to be accurate
column10: I had 49 percent; President Ford
column11: 39 percent. Uh - the polls uh - are good indications of fluctuations
column12: but they vary widely one from another. And the only poll I've ever followed is the one that uh - you know
column13: is taken on election day. I was in uh - thirty primaries in the spring
column14: and uh - at first it was obvious that I didn't have any standing in the poll. As a matter of fact
column15: I think when Gallup ran their first poll in December of 1975 they didn't put my name on the list. They had thirty-five people on the list. My name wasn't even there. And at the beginning of the year I had about 2 percent. So the polls to me are interesting
column16: but they don't determine
column17: you know
column18: my hopes or - or my despair. I campaign among people. I've never depended on powerful political figures to put me in office. I have a direct relationship with hundreds of people around - hundreds of thousands around the country who actively campaign for me. In Georgia alone
column19: for instance
column20: I got 84 percent of the vote
column21: and I think there were fourteen people uh - in addition to myself on the ballot
column22: and Governor Wallace had been very strong in Georgia. That's an overwhelming support from my own people who know me best. And today
column23: we have about five hundred Georgians at their own expense - just working people who believe in me - spread around the country uh - involved in the political campaign. So
column24: the polls are interesting
column25: but uh - I don't know how to explain the fluctuation. I think a lot of it uh - depends on current events - uh - sometimes foreign affairs
column26: sometimes domestic affairs. But I think our hold uh - of support among those who uh - are crucial to the election has been fairly steady. And my success in the primary season was
column27: I think
column29: from someone who's from outside Washington
column30: who - who never has been a part of the Washington establishment. And I think that we'll have good results uh - on November the second for myself and I hope for the country.

column1: I think uh - the uh - increase and the uh - prospects as far as I'm concerned and the I - less favorable prospects for Governor Carter
column2: reflect that Governor Carter uh - is inconsistent in many of the positions that he takes. He tends to distort on a number of occasions. Uh - just a moment ago
column3: for example
column4: uh - he uh - was indicating that uh - uh - in the 1950s
column5: for example
column6: uh - unemployment was very low. He fails to point out that uh - in the 1950s we were engaged in the war in Vietnam. We - I mean in Korea - we had uh - three million five hundred thousand young men uh - in the Army
column7: Navy
column8: Air Force and Marines. That's not the way to end unemployment or to reduce unemployment. At the present time we're at peace. We have reduced the number of people in the Army
column9: Navy
column10: Air Force and Marines from three million
column11: one hundred - three million
column12: five hundred thousand to two mil- lion one hundred thousand. We are not at war. We have reduced the military manpower by a million four hundred thousand. If we had that many more people in the Army
column13: the Navy
column14: the Air Force
column15: and Marines
column16: our unemployment figure would be considerably less. But this administration doesn't believe the way to reduce unemployment is to go to war
column17: or to increase the number of people in the military. So you cannot compare unemployment
column19: uh - with the present time with the 1950s
column20: because the then administration had people in the military - they were at war
column21: they were fighting overseas
column22: and this administration has reduced the size of the military by a million four hundred thousand. They're in the civilian labor market and they're not fighting anywhere around the world today.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.
