column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column1: I believe that if we are inspired, if we can achieve a degree of unity, if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels, then we can achieve great things. column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent

people are healed, are working together', 'The American people are moving again, and moving in the right direction', 'We have cut inflation by better than half', 'We have came out of the recession and were well on the road to real prosperity in this country again', 'There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because Ive been open, candid and forthright', 'I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised', 'We are at peace', 'Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight', 'We have peace with freedom', 'Ive been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times', 'I love America just as all of you love America', 'It would be the highest honor for purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader', 'Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow, to inspire our people to reach infant mortality', 'And our cancer rate is uh  higher than any country in the world', 'We dont have good health care', 'We could have it', 'Employment ought to be restored to our people', 'Weve become 'Our education system can be improved', 'Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained', 'Our housing programs have uh  gone bad', 'It used to be that the average  uh family could own a house', 'But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes', 'The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.
