Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 15)	" For twenty-five years I served in the Congress under five presidents. I saw them work
column4: I saw them make very hard decisions. I didn't always agree with their decisions
column5: whether they were Democratic or Republican presidents. For the last two years
column6: I've been the president
column7: and I have found from experience that it's much more difficult to make those decisions than it is to second-guess them. I became president at the time that the United States was in a very troubled time. We had inflation of over 12 percent
column8: we were on the brink of the worst recession in the last forty years
column9: we were still deeply involved in the problems of Vietnam. The American people had lost faith and trust and confidence in the presidency itself. That uh - situation called for me to first put the United States on a steady course and to keep our keel well balanced
column10: because we had to face the difficult problems that had all of a sudden hit America. I think most people know that I did not seek the presidency. But I am asking for your help and assistance to be president for the next four years. During this campaign we've seen a lot of television shows
column11: a lot of bumper stickers
column12: and a great many uh - slogans of one kind or another. But those are not the things that count. What counts is
column13: that the United States celebrated its 200th birthday on July fourth. As a result of that wonderful experience all over the United States
column14: there is a new spirit in America. The American people are healed
column15: are working together. The American people are moving again
column16: and moving in the right direction. We have cut inflation by better than half. We have came out of the recession and we're well on the road to real prosperity in this country again. There has been a restoration of faith and confidence and trust in the presidency because I've been open
column17: candid and forthright. I have never promised more than I could produce and I have produced everything that I promised. We are at peace. Not a single young American is fighting or dying on any foreign soil tonight. We have peace with freedom. I've been proud to be president of the United States during these very troubled times. I love America just as all of you love America. It would be the highest honor for me to have your support on November second and for you to say
column19: you've done a good job
column20: keep on doing it."" Thank you
column21: and good night.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column1: Thank you Barbara (barely audible). The major purpose of an election for president is to choose a leader. Someone who can analyze the depths of feeling in our country to set a standard for our people to follow
column2: to inspire our people to reach for greatness
column3: to correct our defects
column4: to answer difficult questions
column5: to bind ourselves together in a spirit of unity. I don't believe the present administration has done that. We have been discouraged and we've been alienated. Sometimes we've been embarrassed and sometimes we've been ashamed. Our people are out of work
column6: and there's a sense of withdrawal. But our country is innately very strong. Mr. Ford is a good and decent man
column7: but he's in - been in office now more than eight hundred days approaching almost as long as John Kennedy was in office. I'd like to ask the American people what
column8: what's been accomplished. A lot remains to be done. My own background is different from his. I was a school board member
column9: and a library board member. I served an a hospital authority. And I was in the state senate and I was governor and I'm an engineer
column10: a Naval officer
column11: a farmer
column12: a businessman. And I believe we require someone who can work harmoniously with the Congress
column13: who can work closely with the people of this country
column14: and who can bring a new image and a new spirit to Washington. Our tax structure is a disgrace
column15: it needs to be reformed. I was Governor of Georgia for four years. We never increased sales taxes or income tax or property tax. As a matter of fact
column16: the year before I went out of office we gave a $50 million refund to the property taxpayers of Georgia. We spend six hundred dollars per person in this country - every man
column17: woman and child - for health care. We still rank fifteenth among all the nations of the world in infant mortality. And our cancer rate is uh - higher than any country in the world. We don't have good health care. We could have it. Employment ought to be restored to our people. We've become almost a welfare state. We spend now 700 percent more on unemployment compensation than we did eight years ago when the Republicans took over the White House. Our people wanna go back to work. Our education system can be improved. Secrecy ought to be stripped away from government and a maximum of personal privacy ought to be maintained. Our housing programs have uh - gone bad. It used to be that the average - uh family could own a house. But now less than a third of our people can afford to buy their own homes. The budget was more grossly out of balance last year than ever before in the history of our country - $65 billion - primarily because our people are not at work. Inflation is robbing us
column19: and the government bureaucracy is uh - just a horrible mess. This doesn't have to be. Now I don't know all the answers. Nobody could. But I do know that if the president of the United States and the Congress of the United States and the people of the United States said
column20: ""I believe our nation is greater than what we are now."" I believe that if we are inspired
column21: if we can achieve a degree of unity
column22: if we can set our goals high enough and work toward recognized goals with industry and labor and agriculture along with government at all levels
column23: then we can achieve great things. We might have to do it slowly. There are no magic answers to do it. But I believe together we can make great progress. We can correct our difficult mistakes and answer those very tough questions. I believe in the greatness of our country
column24: and I believe the American people are ready for a change in Washington. We've been drifting too long. We've been dormant too long. We've been discouraged too long. And we have not set an example for our own people. But I believe that we can now establish in the White House a good relationship with Congress
column25: a good relationship with our people
column26: set very high goals for our country. And with inspiration and hard work we can achieve great things. And let the world know - that's very important. But more importantly
column27: let the people in our own country realize that we still live in the greatest nation on earth. Thank you very much.

column3: 2)	" I think the major reason for a decrease in participation that we have experienced ever since 1960 has been the deep discouragement of the American people about the performance of public officials. When you've got seven and a half
column4: eight million people out of work
column5: and you've got three times as much inflation as you had during the last eight-year Democratic administration
column6: when you have the highest deficits in history; when you have it uh - becoming increasingly difficult far a family to put a child through college or to own a home
column7: there's a natural inclination to be turned off. Also
column8: in the aftermath of Vietnam and Cambodia and uh - Watergate and uh - the CIA revelations
column9: people have feel - have felt that they've uh been betrayed by public officials
column10: I have to admit that in the uh - heat of the campaign - I've been in thirty primaries during the springtime
column11: I've been campaigning for twenty-two months - I've made some mistakes. And I think this is uh - uh - part of uh - of just being a human being. I - I have to say that my campaign has been an open one. And uh - the Playboy thing has been of great - very great concern to me. I don't know how to deal with it exactly. Uh - I uh - agreed to give the interview uh - to Playboy Other people have done it who are notable - uh - Governor Jerry Brown
column12: uh - Walter Cronkite
column13: uh - Albert Schweitzer
column14: Mr. Ford's own secretary of the treasury
column15: Mr. Simon
column16: uh - William Buckley - many other people. But they weren't running for president
column17: and in retrospect
column19: I would not have given that uh - interview had I do it - had it - I to do it over again. If I should ever decide in the future to discuss my - my deep Christian beliefs and uh - condemnation and sinfulness
column20: I'll use another forum besides Playboy. But I can say this
column21: uh - I'm doing the best I can to get away from that
column22: and during the next ten days
column23: the American people will not see the Carter campaign running uh - television advertisements and newspaper advertisements based on a personal attack on President Ford's character. I believe that the opposite is true with President Ford's campaign
column24: and uh - I hope that we can leave those issues in this next ten days about personalities and mistakes of the past - we've both made some mistakes - and talk about unemployment
column25: inflation
column26: housing
column27: education
column29: government organization
column30: stripping away of secrecy
column31: and the things that are crucial to the American people. I regret the things in my own long campaign that have been mistaken
column32: but I'm trying to do away with those the last ten days.

column1: I believe that the uh - American people have been turned off in this election
column3: for a variety of reasons. We have seen on Capitol Hill
column4: in the Congress
column5: uh - a great many uh - allegations of wrong-doing
column6: of uh - alleged immorality
column7: uh - those are very disturbing to the American people. They wonder how an elected representative uh - can serve them and participate in such activities uh - serving in the Congress of the United States. Yes
column8: and I'm certain many
column9: many Americans were turned off by the revelations of Watergate
column10: a very
column11: very uh - bad period of time in American political history. Yes
column12: and thousands
column13: maybe millions of Americans were turned off because of the uh - problems that came out of our involvement in Vietnam. But on the other hand
column14: I found on July fourth of this year
column15: a new spirit born in America. We were celebrating our Bicentennial; and I find that uh - there is a - a movement as I travel around the country of greater interest in this campaign. Now
column16: like uh - any hardworking uh - person seeking public office uh - in the campaign
column17: inevitably sometimes you will use uh - rather graphic language and I'm guilty of that just like I think most others in the political arena. But I do make a pledge that in the next ten days when we're asking the American people to make one of the most important decisions in their lifetime
column18: because I think this election is one of the mast vital in the history of America
column19: that uh - we do together what we can to stimulate voter participation.

column3: 4)	" In the last uh - two weeks
column4: I've had a chance to talk to uh - two men who have visited uh - the Soviet Union
column5: Yugoslavia and China. One is Governor Avell- Averell Harriman
column6: who visited the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia
column7: and the other is James Schlesinger
column8: whom I think you accompanied to uh - China. I got a- a complete report back from those countries from these two distinguished - uh - gentlemen. Mr. Harriman talked to the leaders in Yugoslavia
column9: and I think it's accurate to say that there is no uh - prospect in their opinion
column10: of the Soviet Union invading uh - Yugoslavia should uh - Mr. Tito pass away. The present leadership uh - there is uh - is fairly uniform in - in their purpose
column11: and I think it's a close-knit group
column12: uh - and uh - I think it would be unwise for us to say that we will go to war uh - in Yugoslavia uh - if the Soviets should invade
column13: which I think would be an extremely unlikely thing. I have maintained from the very beginning of my campaign
column14: and this was a standard answer that I made in response to the Yugoslavian question
column15: that I would never uh - go to war or become militarily involved
column16: in the internal affairs of another country unless our own security was direc- rectly threatened. And uh - I don't believe that our security would be directly threatened if the Soviet Union went uh - into Yugoslavia. I don't believe it will happen. I certainly hope it won't. I would take eh - the strongest possible measures short of uh - actual military uh - action there by our own troops
column17: but I doubt that that would be an eventuality.

column1: No
I firmly believe
column3: that it's unwise for a president to signal in advance what uh - options he might exercise if any uhh - international problem arose. I think we all recall with some sadness that at uh - the period of the nin- late nineteen forties
column4: early nineteen fifties
column5: there were some indications that the United States would not include uh - South Korea in an area of defense. There are some who allege
column6: I can't prove it true or untrue
column7: that uh - such a statement uh - in effect invited the North Koreans to invade South Korea. It's a fact they did. But no president of the United States
column8: in my opinion
column9: should signal in advance to a prospective enemy
column10: what his uhh - decision might be or what option he might exercise. It's far better for a person sitting in the White House uh - who has a number of options to make certain that the uh - other side
column11: so to speak
column12: doesn't know precisely what you're going to do. And therefore
column13: that was the reason that I would not uh - identify any particular course of action uh - when I responded to a question a week or so ago.

column3: 5)	" I have indicated to General Brown that uh - the words that he used in that interview
column4: in that particular case and in several others
column5: were very ill advised. And General Brown has indicated uh - his apology
column6: his regrets
column7: and I think that will
column8: uh - in this situation
column9: settle the matter. It is tragic that uh - the full transcript of that interview was not released and that there were excerpts
column10: some of the excerpts
column11: taken out of context. Not this one
column12: however
column13: that you bring up. General Brown has an exemply [sic] record of military performance. He served this nation with great
column14: great skill and courage and bravery for thirty-five years. And I think it's the consensus of the people who are knowledgeable in the military field
column15: that he is probably the outstanding military leader and strategist that we have in America today. Now he did use uh - ill-advised words
column16: but I think in the fact that he apologized
column17: that he was reprimanded
column18: uh - does permit him to stay on and continue that kind of leadership that's we so badly need as we enter into uh - negotiations uh - under the SALT II agreement
column19: or if we have operations that might be developing uh in the Middle East or southern Africa
column20: in the Pacific
column21: uh - we need a man with that experience
column22: that knowledge
column23: that know-how
column24: and I think
column25: in light of the fact that he has uh - apologized
column26: uh - would not have justified my asking for his resignation.

column1: Well
column3: I - I think this is uh - the second time that General Brown has made a statement that - for which he did have to apologize. And I know that everybody uh - makes mistakes. I think the first one was related to uh - the unwarranted influence of American Jews on the media and uh - in the Congress. This one concerned uh - Great Britain. I think he said that Israel was a - a military burden on us and that Iran hoped to reestablish the Persian Empire. Ah - I'm not uh - sure that I remembered earlier that President Ford had - had expressed uh - his concern about the statement or apologized for it. This is uh - something
column4: though
column5: that I think uh - is indicative of the need among the American people to know how its commander-in-chief
column6: the president
column7: feels and - and - and I think the only criticism that I would have uh - on - of Mr. Ford is that uh - immediately when the statement was re - re - revealed
column8: uh - perhaps a - a statement from the president would have been a clarifying and a very beneficial thing.

column3: 6)	" I don't believe it does. Uh - I began campaigning uh - twenty-two months ago. At that time
column4: nobody thought I had a chance to win. Uh - very few people knew who I was. I came from a tiny town
column5: as you know
column6: Plains
column7: and didn't hold public office
column8: didn't have very much money. And my first organization was just four or five people plus my wife and my children
column9: my three sons and their wives. And we won the nomination by going out into the streets - barbershops
column10: beauty parlors
column11: restaurants
column12: stores
column13: in factory shift lines also in farmers' markets and livestock sale barns - and we talked a lot and we listened a lot and we learned from the American people. And we built up uh - an awareness among the uh - voters of this country
column14: particularly those in whose primaries I entered - thirty of them
column15: nobody's ever done that before - about who I was and what I stood for. Now we have a very
column16: very wide-ranging group of advisers who help me prepare for these debates and who teach me about international economics
column17: and foreign affairs
column19: health
column20: education
column21: welfare
column22: government reorganization. I'd say
column23: several hundred of them. And they're very fine and very highly qualified. The one major decision that I have made since acquiring the nomination
column24: and I share this with President Ford
column25: is the choice of a vice president. I think this should be indicative of the kind of leaders I would choose to help me if I am elected. I chose Senator Walter Mondale. And the only criterion I ever put forward in my own mind was who among the several million people in this country would be the best person qualified to be president
column26: if something should happen to me and to join me in being vice president if I should serve out my term. And I'm convinced now
column27: more than I was when I got the nomination
column28: that Walter Mondale was the right choice
column29: And I believe this is a good indication of the kind of people I would choose in the future. Mr. Ford has had that same choice to make. I don't want to say anything critical of Senator Dole
column30: but I've never heard Mr. Ford say that that was his prim- primary consideration - Who is the best person I could choose in this country to be president of the United States? I feel completely at ease knowing that someday Senator Mondale might very well be president. In the last five pres- vice presidential uh - nominees
column31: uh - incumbents
column32: three of them have become president. But I think this is indicative of what I would do.

column1: The Governor may not have heard my uh - established criteria for the selection of a vice president
column2: but uh - it was a well-established criteria that the person I selected would be fully qualified to be president of the United States. And Senator Bob Dole is so qualified: sixteen years in the House of Representatives and in the Senate
column3: uhh - very high responsibilities on important committees. I don't mean to be critical of uh - Senator Mondale
column4: but uh - I was uh - very
column5: very surprised when I read that uh - Senator Mondale made a very derogatory
column6: very personal comment about General Brown uh - after the news story that uh - broke about General Brown. If my recollection is correct he indicated that uh - General Brown was not qualified to be a sewer commissioner. I don't think that's a proper way to describe aayuh- chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff who has fought for his country for thirty-five years
column7: and I'm sure the governor would agree with me on that. Uh - I think Senator Dole would show more good judgment and discretion than to so describe uh - a heroic and brave and very outstanding leader of the military. So I think our selection uh - of Bob Dole as vice president uh - is based on merit. And if he should ever become uh - the president of the United States
column8: with his vast experience as member the House and a member of the Senate
column9: as well as a vice president
column10: I think he would do an outstanding job as president of the United States.

column3: 8)	" Yes
column4: I'd be glad to. In the first place
column5: uh - as is the case with the environmental policy and the energy policy that I just described
column6: and the policy for nonproliferation of uh - of nuclear waste
column7: this administration has no urban policy. It's impossible for mayors or governors to cooperate with the resident
column8: because they can't anticipate what's gonna happen next. A mayor of a city like New York
column9: for instance
column10: needs to know uh - eighteen months or two years ahead of time what responsibility the city will have in administration and in financing - in things like housing
column11: uh - pollution control
column12: uh - crime control
column13: education
column14: welfare and health. This has not been done
column15: unfortunately. I remember the headline in the Daily News that said
column16: ""Ford to New York: Drop Dead."" I think it's very important that our cities know that they have a partner in the federal government. Quite often Congress has passed laws in the past designed to help people with uh - the ownership of homes and with the control of crime and with adequate health care and education programs and so forth. Uh - those uh programs were designed to help those who need it most. And quite often this has been in the very poor people and neighborhoods in the downtown urban centers. Because of the uh - great -ly- greatly uh - advantaged uh - tho- per - persons who live in the suburbs
column17: better education
column19: more articulate
column20: more aware of what the laws are
column21: quite often this money has been channeled out of the downtown centers where it's needed. Also I favor all revenue sharing money being used for local governments
column22: and also to remove prohibitions in the use of revenue sharing money so that it can be used to improve education
column23: and health care. We have now uh - for instance only 7 percent of the total education cost being financed by the federal government. When uh - the Nixon-Ford Administration started
column24: this was 10 percent. That's a 30 percent reduction in the portion that the federal government contributes to education in just eight years. And as you know
column25: the education cost has gone up uh - tremendously. The last point is that the major - uh thrust has gotta be to put people back to work. We've got an extraordinarily high unemployment rate among downtown urban ghetto areas

column3: 9)	" Let me say at the outset
column4: uh - I'm very proud of the record of this administration. In the cabinet I have one of the outstanding
column5: I think
column6: administrators as the secretary of transportation
column7: Bill Coleman. You're familiar
column8: I'm sure
column9: with the recognition given in the Air Force to uh - General James
column10: and there was just uh - approved a three-star admiral
column11: the first in the history of the United States Navy
column12: so uh - we are giving full recognition to individuals of quality in the Ford administration in positions of great responsibility. In addition
column13: uh - the Department of Justice is fully enforcing
column14: and enforcing effectively
column15: the Voting Rights Act
column16: the legislation that involves jobs
column17: housing for minorities
column18: not only blacks but all others. Uh - the Department of uh - uh - HUD is enforcing the new legislation that uhh - outlaws
column19: that takes care of redlining. Uh - what we're doing is saying that there are opportunities
column20: business opportunities
column21: educational opportunities
column22: responsibilities uh - where people with talent
column23: black or any other minority
column24: can fully qualify. The Office of Minority Business in the Department of Commerce has made available more money in trying to help uh - black businessmen or other minority businessmen than any other administration since the office was established. The Office of Small Business
column25: under Mr. Kobelinski
column26: has a very massive program trying to help the black community. The individual who wants to start a business or expand his business as a black businessman is able to borrow
column27: either directly or with guaranteed loans. I believe on the record that this administration has been more responsive and we have carried out the law to the letter
column28: and I'm proud of the record.

column1: The uh - description just made of this administration's record is hard to uh - recognize. I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford voted against the uh - Voting Rights Acts and the uh - Civil Rights Acts in their uh - debative stage I think once it was assured they were going to pass he finally voted for it. This country uh - changed drastically in 1969 when the uh - terms of John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson were over and Richard Nixon and - and Gerald Ford became the presidents. There was a time when there was hope for those who uh - were poor and downtrodden and who were - uh elderly or who were - uh ill or who were in minority groups
column2: but that time has been gone. I think the greatest thing that ever happened to the South was the passage of the Civil Rights Act and the opening up of opportunities - uh to black people - the chance to vote
column3: to hold a job
column4: to buy a house
column5: to go to school
column6: and to participate in public affairs. It not only liberated - uh black people but it also liberated the whites. We've seen uh - in many instances in recent years a minority affairs uh - section of uh Small Loan Administration
column7: uh - Small Business Administration lend uh - a black entrepreneur just enough money to get started
column8: and then to go bankrupt. The bankruptcies have gone up - uh in an extraordinary degree. Uh - FHA
column9: which used to be a very responsible agency
column10: uh - that everyone looked to to help own a home
column11: lost six million dollars last year. There've been over thirteen hundred indictments in HUD
column12: over eight hundred convictions relating just to home loans. And now the federal government has become the world's greatest slum landlord. We've got a 30 percent or 40 percent unemployment rate among minority uh - young people. And there's been no concerted effort given to the needs of those who are both poor and black
column13: or poor and who speak a foreign language. And that's where there's been a great uh generation of despair
column14: and ill health

column8: I'm sure

column10: and there was just uh - approved a three-star admiral

column12: so uh - we are giving full recognition to individuals of quality in the Ford administration in positions of great responsibility. In addition

column14: and enforcing effectively

column16: the legislation that involves jobs
column17: housing for minorities

column20: business opportunities

column22: responsibilities uh - where people with talent
column23: black or any other minority

column25: under Mr. Kobelinski
column26: has a very massive program trying to help the black community. The individual who wants to start a business or expand his business as a black businessman is able to borrow

column1: The uh - description just made of this administration's record is hard to uh - recognize. I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford voted against the uh - Voting Rights Acts and the uh - Civil Rights Acts in their uh - debative stage I think once it was assured they were going to pass he finally voted for it. This country uh - changed drastically in 1969 when the uh - terms of John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson were over and Richard Nixon and - and Gerald Ford became the presidents. There was a time when there was hope for those who uh - were poor and downtrodden and who were - uh elderly or who were - uh ill or who were in minority groups
column2: but that time has been gone. I think the greatest thing that ever happened to the South was the passage of the Civil Rights Act and the opening up of opportunities - uh to black people - the chance to vote
column3: to hold a job
column4: to buy a house
column5: to go to school
column6: and to participate in public affairs. It not only liberated - uh black people but it also liberated the whites. We've seen uh - in many instances in recent years a minority affairs uh - section of uh Small Loan Administration
column7: uh - Small Business Administration lend uh - a black entrepreneur just enough money to get started
column8: and then to go bankrupt. The bankruptcies have gone up - uh in an extraordinary degree. Uh - FHA
column9: which used to be a very responsible agency
column10: uh - that everyone looked to to help own a home
column11: lost six million dollars last year. There've been over thirteen hundred indictments in HUD
column12: over eight hundred convictions relating just to home loans. And now the federal government has become the world's greatest slum landlord. We've got a 30 percent or 40 percent unemployment rate among minority uh - young people. And there's been no concerted effort given to the needs of those who are both poor and black
column13: or poor and who speak a foreign language. And that's where there's been a great uh generation of despair
column14: and ill health
column15: and the lack of education
column16: lack of purposefulness
column17: and the lack of hope for the future. But it doesn't take just a quiet uh - dormant uh minimum enforcement of the law. It requires an aggressive searching out and reaching out to help people who especially need it. And that's been lacking in the last eight years.

column3: 9)	" Let me say at the outset
column4: uh - I'm very proud of the record of this administration. In the cabinet I have one of the outstanding
column5: I think
column6: administrators as the secretary of transportation
column7: Bill Coleman. You're familiar
column8: I'm sure
column9: with the recognition given in the Air Force to uh - General James
column10: and there was just uh - approved a three-star admiral
column11: the first in the history of the United States Navy
column12: so uh - we are giving full recognition to individuals of quality in the Ford administration in positions of great responsibility. In addition
column13: uh - the Department of Justice is fully enforcing
column14: and enforcing effectively
column15: the Voting Rights Act
column16: the legislation that involves jobs
column17: housing for minorities
column18: not only blacks but all others. Uh - the Department of uh - uh - HUD is enforcing the new legislation that uhh - outlaws
column19: that takes care of redlining. Uh - what we're doing is saying that there are opportunities
column20: business opportunities
column21: educational opportunities
column22: responsibilities uh - where people with talent
column23: black or any other minority
column24: can fully qualify. The Office of Minority Business in the Department of Commerce has made available more money in trying to help uh - black businessmen or other minority businessmen than any other administration since the office was established. The Office of Small Business
column25: under Mr. Kobelinski
column26: has a very massive program trying to help the black community. The individual who wants to start a business or expand his business as a black businessman is able to borrow
column27: either directly or with guaranteed loans. I believe on the record that this administration has been more responsive and we have carried out the law to the letter
column28: and I'm proud of the record.

column1: The uh - description just made of this administration's record is hard to uh - recognize. I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford voted against the uh - Voting Rights Acts and the uh - Civil Rights Acts in their uh - debative stage I think once it was assured they were going to pass he finally voted for it. This country uh - changed drastically in 1969 when the uh - terms of John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson were over and Richard Nixon and - and Gerald Ford became the presidents. There was a time when there was hope for those who uh - were poor and downtrodden and who were - uh elderly or who were - uh ill or who were in minority groups
column2: but that time has been gone. I think the greatest thing that ever happened to the South was the passage of the Civil Rights Act and the opening up of opportunities - uh to black people - the chance to vote
column3: to hold a job
column4: to buy a house
column5: to go to school
column6: and to participate in public affairs. It not only liberated - uh black people but it also liberated the whites. We've seen uh - in many instances in recent years a minority affairs uh - section of uh Small Loan Administration
column7: uh - Small Business Administration lend uh - a black entrepreneur just enough money to get started
column8: and then to go bankrupt. The bankruptcies have gone up - uh in an extraordinary degree. Uh - FHA
column9: which used to be a very responsible agency
column10: uh - that everyone looked to to help own a home
column11: lost six million dollars last year. There've been over thirteen hundred indictments in HUD
column12: over eight hundred convictions relating just to home loans. And now the federal government has become the world's greatest slum landlord. We've got a 30 percent or 40 percent unemployment rate among minority uh - young people. And there's been no concerted effort given to the needs of those who are both poor and black
column13: or poor and who speak a foreign language. And that's where there's been a great uh generation of despair
column14: and ill health
column15: and the lack of education
column16: lack of purposefulness
column17: and the lack of hope for the future. But it doesn't take just a quiet uh - dormant uh minimum enforcement of the law. It requires an aggressive searching out and reaching out to help people who especially need it. And that's been lacking in the last eight years.

column3: 9)	" Let me say at the outset
column4: uh - I'm very proud of the record of this administration. In the cabinet I have one of the outstanding
column5: I think
column6: administrators as the secretary of transportation
column7: Bill Coleman. You're familiar
column8: I'm sure
column9: with the recognition given in the Air Force to uh - General James
column10: and there was just uh - approved a three-star admiral
column11: the first in the history of the United States Navy
column12: so uh - we are giving full recognition to individuals of quality in the Ford administration in positions of great responsibility. In addition
column13: uh - the Department of Justice is fully enforcing
column14: and enforcing effectively
column15: the Voting Rights Act
column16: the legislation that involves jobs
column17: housing for minorities
column18: not only blacks but all others. Uh - the Department of uh - uh - HUD is enforcing the new legislation that uhh - outlaws
column19: that takes care of redlining. Uh - what we're doing is saying that there are opportunities
column20: business opportunities
column21: educational opportunities
column22: responsibilities uh - where people with talent
column23: black or any other minority
column24: can fully qualify. The Office of Minority Business in the Department of Commerce has made available more money in trying to help uh - black businessmen or other minority businessmen than any other administration since the office was established. The Office of Small Business
column25: under Mr. Kobelinski
column26: has a very massive program trying to help the black community. The individual who wants to start a business or expand his business as a black businessman is able to borrow
column27: either directly or with guaranteed loans. I believe on the record that this administration has been more responsive and we have carried out the law to the letter
column28: and I'm proud of the record.

column1: The uh - description just made of this administration's record is hard to uh - recognize. I think it's accurate to say that Mr. Ford voted against the uh - Voting Rights Acts and the uh - Civil Rights Acts in their uh - debative stage I think once it was assured they were going to pass he finally voted for it. This country uh - changed drastically in 1969 when the uh - terms of John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson were over and Richard Nixon and - and Gerald Ford became the presidents. There was a time when there was hope for those who uh - were poor and downtrodden and who were - uh elderly or who were - uh ill or who were in minority groups
column2: but that time has been gone. I think the greatest thing that ever happened to the South was the passage of the Civil Rights Act and the opening up of opportunities - uh to black people - the chance to vote
column3: to hold a job
column4: to buy a house
column5: to go to school
column6: and to participate in public affairs. It not only liberated - uh black people but it also liberated the whites. We've seen uh - in many instances in recent years a minority affairs uh - section of uh Small Loan Administration
column7: uh - Small Business Administration lend uh - a black entrepreneur just enough money to get started
column8: and then to go bankrupt. The bankruptcies have gone up - uh in an extraordinary degree. Uh - FHA
column9: which used to be a very responsible agency
column10: uh - that everyone looked to to help own a home
column11: lost six million dollars last year. There've been over thirteen hundred indictments in HUD
column12: over eight hundred convictions relating just to home loans. And now the federal government has become the world's greatest slum landlord. We've got a 30 percent or 40 percent unemployment rate among minority uh - young people. And there's been no concerted effort given to the needs of those who are both poor and black
column13: or poor and who speak a foreign language. And that's where there's been a great uh generation of despair
column14: and ill health
column15: and the lack of education
column16: lack of purposefulness
column17: and the lack of hope for the future. But it doesn't take just a quiet uh - dormant uh minimum enforcement of the law. It requires an aggressive searching out and reaching out to help people who especially need it. And that's been lacking in the last eight years.
